title: 112_hr2235
content: The Act titled "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" provides enhanced protections for vulnerable unaccompanied alien children and female detainees. The Act mandates live training for personnel interacting with unaccompanied alien children on legal authorities and procedures. It also ensures timely transportation and placement of children in the care of the Office of Refugee Resettlement within 72 hours of apprehension. The Act mandates timely transportation and placement of children in the care of the Office of Refugee Resettlement within 72 hours of apprehension, with exceptions for natural disasters. Female officers must be present during the transfer of female detainees. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide trained staff resources at major ports of entry for unaccompanied alien children. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 mandates the safe transportation of unaccompanied alien children to the Office of Refugee Resettlement. This includes providing emergency medical care, mental health services, bedding, nutrition, and proper temporary care while in Department of Homeland Security custody. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 requires unaccompanied alien children in Department of Homeland Security custody to receive adequate nutrition, a safe living environment, educational materials, and access to recreational programs. The Secretary of Homeland Security must notify the Office of Refugee Resettlement for the child's transfer and placement. Unaccompanied alien children must be provided with a video orientation and notice of their rights by an independent licensed social worker upon apprehension. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure unaccompanied children in custody receive written and video notice of their rights under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including the right to relief from removal and to confer with counsel. The information must be available in English and the five most common native languages spoken by the children. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must maintain confidentiality of information related to unaccompanied alien children in their care, only sharing when authorized by the child or to prevent harm. They must also establish child protection policies, including reliable age determinations for children. The proposed measures aim to ensure reliable age determinations for children without using forensic testing, facilitate safe repatriation of unaccompanied alien children, and defer removal if facing life-threatening harm. The proposed measures aim to ensure the safe separation of unaccompanied alien children from adults and other inmates with criminal backgrounds, in line with the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974.
